name: Himalayan giant honey bee
Appearance: The Himalayan Giant Honeybee, or Apis laboriosa, earns its name with its large size compared to other honeybee species. These bees typically measure around 17 to 20 millimeters in length and have distinctive dark brown to black coloration. They are easily recognizable by their robust build and loud buzzing flight.
Habitat: Apis laboriosa is native to the Himalayan region, where it inhabits rugged mountainous terrain at high altitudes. They construct their large, single-comb nests on cliff faces or rocky overhangs, often at altitudes exceeding 2,500 meters.
Behavior: Himalayan Giant Honeybees exhibit highly social behavior, living in colonies consisting of a queen, drones, and worker bees. They are known for their remarkable ability to withstand cold temperatures and forage at high altitudes, making them well-adapted to their mountainous habitat.

flowers.description: The vibrant flowers of various Rhododendron species are favored by Himalayan Giant Honeybees. In Nepali, Rhododendron is known as Gurans.
environments: Partial shade to full sun exposure

flowers.description: The pinkish-white blossoms of Prunus cerasoides are also attractive to Apis laboriosa. In Nepali, this tree is called Pajaru.
Some species of Aconitum, commonly known as Monkshood, are visited by Himalayan Giant Honeybees for their nectar. In Nepali, Aconitum is known as Bhikshachin or Vatsnabh.
benefits: Historically used in poisons and potions

name: Red dwarf honey bee
Appearance: Apis florea, commonly known as the Dwarf Honeybee, is characterized by its diminutive size and distinctive coloration. With a body length of approximately 7 to 9 millimeters, these bees are notably smaller than other honeybee species. They feature a yellowish-brown thorax and abdomen, often with darker bands or stripes. Despite their small stature, Apis florea possesses the same general body structure as other honeybees, including wings and specialized mouthparts for collecting nectar and pollen.
Habitat: Apis florea is native to regions of South and Southeast Asia, where it thrives in warm climates with abundant floral resources. These bees are well-adapted to a variety of habitats, including tropical forests, savannas, and agricultural landscapes. They construct small, exposed nests in protected locations, such as tree branches, rock crevices, or human-made structures, where they build intricate honeycomb structures to rear their young.
Behavior: The behavior of Apis florea is characterized by its social structure and foraging habits. Like other honeybee species, Apis florea lives in colonies consisting of a queen, drones, and worker bees. These bees exhibit remarkable cooperation and communication within their colonies, working together to gather nectar and pollen, care for the brood, and defend their nest from potential threats. Apis florea is also known for its swarming behavior, during which a colony splits to establish a new nest site.

flowers.description: Apis florea is attracted to the flowers of Euryale ferox, a floating aquatic plant native to Asia. In Nepali, it is commonly known as  (Makhana).
benefits: Edible seeds used in Asian cuisine

flowers.description: The vibrant red flowers of Erythrina variegata are another favorite of Apis florea. In Nepali, this tree is known as Mandar.
Apis florea is also drawn to the small, inconspicuous flowers of various Amaranthus species. In Nepali, Amaranthus is known as (Latte Saag)
benefits: Used in traditional dishes and herbal remedies

name: Asian honeybee
Appearance: Apis cerana, or the Eastern Honeybee, is similar in appearance to the Western Honeybee but slightly smaller. They have a compact body with golden-brown coloration and darker bands across the abdomen.
Habitat: Apis cerana is found throughout South and Southeast Asia, inhabiting a variety of habitats including forests, grasslands, and agricultural landscapes. They typically nest in tree hollows, rock crevices, or man-made structures.
Behavior: Apis cerana is a highly adaptable and social species, living in colonies with a queen, drones, and worker bees. They are known for their efficiency as pollinators and their ability to thrive in diverse environments.

flowers.description: The small, white flowers of the Neem tree are favored by Apis cerana for their nectar.
The vibrant red flowers of the Ashoka tree are another favorite of Apis cerana. In Nepali, this tree is known as Mandar.
The colorful clusters of flowers on the Lantana plant are also visited by Apis cerana. In Nepali, Lantana is known as Chandni or Sugandhan.
environments: Tolerant of drought and poor soils
benefits: Attracts a wide range of pollinators
Variety of colors enhances garden aesthetics
Can be used to control erosion

name: Rock bee
Appearance: Apis dorsata, also known as the Giant Honeybee, is notable for its large size and distinctive behavior.
Habitat: Found in tropical and subtropical regions across South and Southeast Asia.
Behavior: Known for defensive behavior and elaborate nest-building process.

flowers.description: The small, white flowers of the Neem tree are favored by Apis dorsata for their nectar.
The vibrant red flowers of the Ashoka tree attract Apis dorsata.
Apis dorsata is also drawn to the colorful clusters of Lantana camara.

name: European honey bee
Appearance: Commonly known as the Western Honeybee, shares similarities with other species but is often slightly larger.
Habitat: Native to Europe, Africa, and the Middle East but introduced worldwide.
Behavior: Known for its social behavior and efficient foraging strategies.

flowers.description: Apis mellifera is attracted to the flowers of various Crotalaria species.
The flowers of Eucalyptus trees are visited by both Giant Honeybees and Western Honeybees.
Clover flowers are popular with both Apis dorsata and Apis mellifera.

name: Arcifera Stingless Bee
Appearance: A petite and striking insect with a body length ranging from 3 to 5 millimeters.
Habitat: Thrives in the lush tropical forests of Southeast Asia.
Behavior: Characterized by their harmonious and industrious nature.

flowers.description: These bees are drawn to the striking purple blossoms of the Malabar Melastome.
benefits: Attracts a wide range of pollinators

flowers.description: Known as Simpoh Air, its large, showy yellow flowers attract these bees.
Known as the Rock Orchid, it provides a rich source of nectar for these industrious bees.
benefits: Can be cultivated on trees or rocks
